detaileddescription.para: This header holds important data and definitions used throughout the program

memberdef.name: eight_milliseconds
memberdef.initializer: std::chrono::nanoseconds(8000000) /* Change if we decide to use microsecond precision, etc., instead of nano. */

detaileddescription.para: Refer to RESOLUTION_X_BASE_VALUE and RESOLUTION_Y_BASE_VALUE only for telling the OS or renderer how large our window should be. Everything else should refer to windowSizeX() and windowSizeY(). RESOLUTION_X_BASE_VALUE and RESOLUTION_Y_BASE_VALUE give only the number of LOGICAL pixels, which can be represented by a varying number of physical pixels, depending on DPI settings.

Refer to RESOLUTION_X_BASE_VALUE and RESOLUTION_Y_BASE_VALUE only for telling the OS or renderer how large our window should be. Everything else should refer to windowSizeX() and windowSizeY(). RESOLUTION_X_BASE_VALUE and RESOLUTION_Y_BASE_VALUE give only the number of LOGICAL pixels, which can be represented by a varying number of physical pixels, depending on DPI settings.

Any function that needs information about the size of the window should refer to windowSizeX() or windowSizeY(). Unlike RESOLUTION_X_BASE_VALUE and RESOLUTION_Y_BASE_VALUE, these values will vary depending on our DPI settings. windowSizeX() and windowSizeY() always give the ACTUAL number of pixels, regardless of DPI settings.

Any function that needs information about the size of the window should refer to windowSizeX() or windowSizeY(). Unlike RESOLUTION_X_BASE_VALUE and RESOLUTION_Y_BASE_VALUE, these values will vary depending on our DPI settings. windowSizeX() and windowSizeY() always give the ACTUAL number of pixels, regardless of DPI settings.
Returns the current resolution. Delete when done using.
Returns the current resolution, with no adjustments made for DPI. Use with caution. Delete when done using.
